definition[0]: when a business or a person has money or goods that can be sold to pay debts
definition[2]: the amount of money in an economy at a particular time
example[0]: The central bank injected liquidity into the economy  (=increased liquidity) last month when it began repurchasing government bonds.
definition[3]: when investments can easily be bought and sold on a particular financial market
example[1]: As investors learned in the last stock market crash, liquidity can disappear quickly when everyone tries to sell at once.
definition[4]: the ability of a company to make payments to employees and suppliers, interest payments to banks etc
example[2]: Disappointing sales and resulting losses have caused liquidity problems.
definition[5]: the ability of a bank to pay back people and organizations that have put money in the bank and that want to take their money out
example[3]: Customers began withdrawing deposits, causing difficulties for the liquidity of the bank.
